sections.text:
Orbital-Induced Crossover of the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov Phase into Abrikosov-like States
Tommy Kotte,1, ∗ Hannes Kühne,1 John A Schlueter,2, 3 Gertrud Zwicknagl,4 and J. Wosnitza1, 5
1Hochfeld-Magnetlabor Dresden (HLD-EMFL) and Würzburg-Dresden Cluster of Excellence ct.qmat, Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, 01328 Dresden, Germany
2Materials Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, USA 3Division of Materials Research, National Science Foundation, Alexandria, VA 22314, USA
4Institute for Mathematical Physics, Technische Universität Braunschweig, 38106 Braunschweig, Germany 5Institut für Festkörper- und Materialphysik, TU Dresden, 01062 Dresden, Germany
(Dated: May 9, 2022)
The Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov (FFLO) state can emerge in superconductors for which the orbital critical field exceeds the Pauli limit. Here, we present angular-resolved specific-heat data of the quasi-two-dimensional organic superconductor κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2, with a focus on high fields in the regime of the FFLO transition. For an increasing out-of-plane tilt of the applied magnetic field, which leads to an increase of orbital contributions, we found that the nature of the superconducting transition changes from second to first order and that a further transition appears within the high-field superconducting phase. However, the superconducting state above the Pauli limit is stable for field tilt of several degrees. Since any finite perpendicular component of the magnetic field necessarily leads to quantization of the orbital motion, the resulting vortex lattice states compete with the modulated order parameter of the FFLO state leading to complex high-field superconducting phases. By solving the linearized self-consistency equation within weakcoupling BCS theory, we show that our results are clear experimental evidence of an orbital-induced transformation of the FFLO order-parameter into Abrikosov-like states of higher Landau levels.
In spin-singlet type-II superconductors, the superconducting (SC) state is suppressed if an applied magnetic field reaches one of two limits: (i) the orbital critical field, Horb, at which the Cooper pairs are broken by the Lorentz force [1], or (ii) the Pauli-limiting field, HP , at which the binding energy of the Cooper pairs is compensated by Zeeman splitting [2, 3]. In most materials, HP exceeds Horb considerably, and the normal-conducting (NC) state is restored at Horb via a second-order phase transition, which is well described by the WerthamerHelfand-Hohenberg (WHH) model [4].
However, Horb can be significantly enhanced to above the Pauli limit for superconductors yielding quasiparticles of high effective masses or for those with a pronounced anisotropy [5, 6]. Fulde and Ferrell [7], as well as Larkin and Ovchinnikov [8], have independently shown that, in this case, the suppression of superconductivity at HP may be avoided by the formation of Cooper pairs with a finite center-of-mass momentum and an associated spatial modulation of the SC order parameter. Although an anisotropic Fermi surface can stabilize this Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov (FFLO) state [9], its formation requires the material to be in the clean limit [10] and a Maki parameter √ 2Horb/HP larger than 1.8 [11]. Quasi-two-dimensional (Q2D) organic superconductors [12, 13] are among the few known materials that fulfill these conditions [5, 14, 15]. Consequentially, the FFLO state was first experimentally verified, by thermodynamic means, in this class of materials [16–18].
∗ t.kotte@hzdr.de
Thorough investigations of the high-field properties established some hallmarks of the FFLO phase, i.e., a reincrease of the SC phase boundary at low temperatures [16, 17, 19–22], the appearance of a first-order transition close to HP [18, 22], and an enhancement of the T1relaxation rate, measured by nuclear magnetic resonance, in the vicinity of the FFLO phase boundary [23, 24].
The continuing search for these experimental signatures led to recent reports of FFLO physics in multiple classes of superconductors, including heavy-fermion compounds [25, 26], iron-based superconductors [27–29], and a transition-metal dichalcogenide [30]. Still, clear experimental confirmations of the FFLO phase remain rare. A major difficulty lies in the fact that the properties of the FFLO state are non-universal depending upon the normal-state quasiparticles and their interactions [31]. In addition, the modulation of the SC order parameter can be masked by competing effects arising in high fields, such as by spin density waves in the Q phase of CeCoIn5 [25]. Finally, the inevitable presence of orbital effects leads to deviations of the order parameter from the original FFLO prediction, which assumes a one-dimensional modulation [9, 32–34]. The resulting effects on the experimental signatures of the FFLO state are not well understood at this time. Q2D organic superconductors offer the unique possibility to study the evolution of the FFLO phase with increasing orbital contribution, since Horb can effectively be controlled by tilting the applied field away from the SC planes [9, 32].
In this Letter, we present angular-resolved specificheat data of the Q2D organic superconductor κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 [with ET = bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene], focusing on the orbital suppression

of the high-field SC phase that is well established as a realization of the FFLO state [16, 18–21, 23, 35, 36]. We found the NC-FFLO transition to be of second order for fields applied precisely in plane, where orbital effects are negligible [37]. Rotating the field away from the in-plane orientation leads to an increase of orbital effects and changes the nature of the transition to first order. Before the high-field (FFLO) superconductivity is finally suppressed by orbital effects, our data indicate a transition to a further SC state. All observations are in line with theoretical predictions of a successive conversion of the FFLO order parameter into an Abrikosov-like one of higher-order Landau levels by increasing orbital contributions [9, 32], and represent a general phenomenology of Q2D Pauli-limited superconductors.
We measured the specific heat of a κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 single crystal (3 × 1 × 0.6 mm3, 4.42 mg), grown by the standard electrolytic method [38]. The sample was attached to a 360° piezo-driven rotator and placed into a 22 T cryomagnet with 3He insert [39]. The rotation axis was approximately parallel to the crystallographic b axis. We determined the specific heat, C, using a continuous relaxation method that allows to detect thermal hystereses and is particularly sensitive to first-order transitions [17, 39, 40]. We aligned the field in plane by maximizing the transition temperature Tc as function of the rotation angle α of the sample in a field of 14 T.
Figure 1(a) shows the heat capacity of the sample in zero field, as well as in the NC state for a field of 14 T, applied perpendicular to the ET layers. The SC transition at Tc ≈ 9.1 K appears as a broad shoulder in the zerofield data. The data agree with literature [16, 41–43].

FIG. 2. Temperature dependence of ∆C/T of κ(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 for different fields applied (a) parallel to the ET layers and (b) with an off-alignment of α = 1.4°. Tlow is marked by vertical dashed lines for comparison.
Figure 2(a) shows the specific heat of κ(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 divided by T for different fields between 0 and 21.7 T, applied parallel to the ET layers. The NC specific heat, shown in Fig. 1(a), is subtracted from the data, leaving only the change in the electronic specific heat ∆C stemming from the SC transition. For all fields, the SC transition manifests as a λ-like anomaly in ∆C/T , and shifts to lower temperatures with increasing field.
Figure 1(b) shows the phase diagram extracted from the peak positions in ∆C. Up to 6 T, Tc shifts only slightly with field. Applying the WHH extrapolation [4], we estimate the orbital critical field from the initial slope dHc/dT |T=T c as about 260 T, exceeding HP [16] by more than an order of magnitude. At intermediate fields, the slope of the phase boundary decreases up to 19.3 T. However, above about 20 T, an upturn of the phase boundary below 4 K occurs, representing a hallmark of the FFLO state [9, 44]. This phase diagram is in agreement with specific-heat measurements by Lortz et al., although they observed additional peaks in the specific heat above 21 T [16].
Turning to the question of the stability of the FFLO state against orbital effects, we performed angularresolved specific-heat measurements at 21.3 T (Fig. 3).
3
In panels (a)-(l) of Fig. 3, ∆C/T is plotted for increasing α, which is defined as the angle between H and the ET layers. For an in-plane field orientation [Fig. 3(a)], a broad (triangular) peak marks the transition from the NC to the FFLO state at Tc = 3.2 K [see also Fig. 2(a)]. For slight off-orientations up to α ≈ 0.5°, the shape of the specific-heat anomaly and Tc do not change [Fig. 3(b)]. For α between 0.8° and 1.8°, the broad transition is superimposed by a peak at Tlow [Figs. 3(c)-3(g)]. This feature, first evolving at Tlow ≈ Tc for α = 0.8°, sharpens and shifts to lower temperature with increasing α. Above about 2.0°, a second peak appears at Thigh [Fig. 3(h)3(l)]. For α = 2.04°, Thigh is exactly at the in-plane Tc. With further increasing α, both peaks sharpen considerably and shift down in temperature. Two observations are remarkable: (i) As shown exemplarily for α = 2.04° in Fig. 3(m), both peaks are hysteretic when comparing the heating (superscript H) and the relaxation (R) branches of the continuous specific-heat measurements. In contrast, for in-plane alignment [Fig. 3(n)], no hysteresis is observed. (ii) The low-temperature peak superimposes the broad triangular peak that signals the SC transition and stretches to at least 4 K for α ≤ 1.8°. However, with the appearance of the second sharp first-order peak, the transition, as well as its extend at Tc change and the NC state (i.e., ∆C = 0) is recovered at temperatures right above the peak [Fig. 3(i)].
For off-alignments beyond α = 2.7°, the thermalrelaxation curves indicate non-equilibrium behavior and a determination of the specific heat is not possible anymore. As shown in Fig. 3(o), the relaxation curves for α between 2.93° and 3.32° show a sudden jump-like increase in temperature, corresponding to an abrupt release of latent heat of up to 0.16 Jmol−1 at α = 3.32°. With increasing α, the jump continuously shifts to lower temperatures, whereas its height increases. Finally, for α ≥ 3.5°, the NC state is recovered and the thermal relaxation becomes featureless. We observed qualitatively similar behavior for negative rotation angles and at 21.7 T, which confirms the intrinsic nature of these non-equilibrium heat releases [39].
In contrast to the peak at Thigh, the signature at Tlow decouples from the SC transition with increasing α. This indicates a further transition within the high-field SC state. In order to examine if this transition is unique to the FFLO state, we measured the specific heat for a slight off-alignment (α = 1.4°) at various fields [Fig. 2(b)]. We found that the sharp signature, which occurs a few hundred mK below Tc, persist down to at least 6 T, proving that it is not unique to the high-field phase.
The SC phase boundary, calculated under the assumption of an isotropic in-plane Fermi velocity vF [15] and s-wave pairing [dashed line in Fig. 1(b)], yields an excellent agreement with the phase boundary determined by
4
means of specific heat. Accordingly, the FFLO state stabilizes below the tricritical point at T ∗ = 0.56Tc ≈ 5.1 K
and above µ0Hc(T ∗) ≈ 19.3 T.
In a next step, we discuss the suppression of the FFLO phase with increasing tilt angle α. As the main result of our work, Fig. 4(e) provides a T -α phase diagram of the SC state in κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 at 21.3 T. We show a contour plot of ∆C/T , interpolated from the data presented in Fig. 3. Additionally, the first-order transitions at Tlow and Thigh are marked by black and orange circles, respectively.
Three observations are noteworthy: (i) The SC transition temperature is nearly unaffected up to α = 2°. This is in stark contrast to β′′-(ET)2SF5CH2CF2SO3, for which the FFLO phase is already suppressed for α > 0.5° [17]. (ii) A second high-field SC phase emerges between α = 0.8° and 3°. (iii) The SC transition crosses over from a second-order behavior for α < 2° to a pronounced first-order one, before superconductivity is finally suppressed around 3.5°. The last observation explains the controversy that some studies claim the NC-FFLO to be of second order [18, 21] while other found evidence for a first-order transition [16].
Theoretical considerations of the SC phase diagram for Q2D superconductors in the presence of paramagnetic as well as orbital effects predict that, below T ∗, the Abrikosov solution [45] for the SC order parameter becomes unstable against the formation of multi-quanta states of higher Landau indices n [9, 32–34, 46]. Hence, for increasing orbital contributions (i.e., increasing α), the FFLO order parameter (corresponding to n→∞) is expected to transform into the Abrikosov lattice (n = 0) via intermediate states of higher n. For BCS superconductors in the weak-coupling limit, the linearized selfconsistency equation, describing the upper critical field as function of T , n, and α, is given in Ref. [9], Eq. (2.9). Introducing the characteristic fields
H̄Z = πkBTc µB ; H̄orb = Φ0 2π ( πkBTc ~vF )2 , (1)
and recognizing the Laguerre polynomial Ln, the selfconsistency equation can be simplified to

Thereby, kB is the Boltzmann constant, ~ the reduced Planck constant, µB the Bohr magneton, and Φ0 the magnetic flux quantum [39].
By solving Eq. (2) numerically, we obtain the phase diagram of κ-ET2Cu(NCS)2 for various angles α. We focus on the lowest Landau levels, since those are stabilized by increased off-alignment. However, the solution of Eq. (2) converges to the FFLO result for high n and small α [9, 34, 39]. We estimate H̄orb from the initial slope
dHc2 dT ∣∣ T=Tc
= −0.66 T K−1 for fields applied perpendicular to the SC layers [16, 39].
The calculated H-T -phase boundaries for the nth Landau states are shown in Figs. 4 (a)-(d) for selected angles α [39]. The ground state at a given T and α is provided by the state with the highest critical field. Compared to Fig. 1(b), the weak-coupling calculation [Eq. (2)] underestimates the phase boundaries. Indeed, κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 is a strong-coupling super-
5 conductor [42, 43]. The jump in the specific heat at zero field ∆Cγ−1T−1c = 2.3 is enhanced by a factor of η2Hc = 1.6 compared to the universal BCS value of 1.43. Similar strong-coupling enhancement factors of the thermodynamic critical field ηHc are found in the wellstudied strong-coupling superconductors Hg and Pb in which they lead to a temperature-dependent enhancement of the orbital critical field by a factor of 1.2-1.3 [47]. Dividing the calculated FFLO phase boundary of κ-ET2Cu(NCS)2 [dashed line in Fig. 1(b)] by 1.32, leads to a perfect agreement with the phase boundaries calculated from Eq. (2) in the high-n limit [Fig. 4(a)].
Figure 4(f) shows the critical temperatures of the first Landau levels as function of α at about 21.3 T. We multiplied these data accordingly by 1.32 in order to compare them to the field studied in Fig. 4(e). The curves reproduce our main experimental results: (i) The pure FFLO state is rapidly suppressed by tilting the field away from the SC planes. However, with increasing angle up to α ≈ 0.7°, the FFLO state is replaced by a cascade of closely lying higher-order Landau states [Fig. 4(b)], which prevent a suppression of Tc by the increasing orbital effects. It is likely that the strong fluctuations in κ-ET2Cu(NCS)2 [16, 21, 48] mask individual transitions. (ii) For intermediate off-alignment (α ≥ 1.3°), only the first two Landau levels exceed the Abrikosov state and their transitions are well separated [Fig. 4(c)]. Considering the Ginzburg-Landau functional close to T ∗, it has been predicted that the SC-NC transition may turn first order for low T and n, if orbital effects are increased [34, 49]. This is confirmed by the first-order signature found at Thigh in the specific-heat data. (iii) Once α exceeds 1.8°, the increase of orbital effects cannot be compensated anymore by a structural adaptation of the SC order parameter. Hence, Tc is strongly reduced by a further tilt of the field. Finally, the high-field SC state is suppressed at α = 3.3°, above which no solution for Eq. (2) exists. An underlying d-wave symmetry of the order parameter would not change qualitatively the angular dependence of Tc and higher-order Landau states are still required to explain the observed angular stability [39].
At first, it seems possible that the feature at Tlow
marks a second transition between Landau states. Since it persist down to low fields [20], an overlayed vortexmelting transition is more likely [48, 50]. For perpendicular field geometry, vortex melting in κ-ET2Cu(NCS)2 has been studied extensively [48, 50–52]. However, the Tlow feature is not essential for our main finding, namely the angular-dependent transition between FFLO and Abrikosov-like states.
Details of the T -α phase diagram might be further altered by (i) strong-coupling effects [53], (ii) interlayer coupling [54], (iii) fluctuations [55], (iv) spin-orbit coupling [56] and, (v) to a smaller extend, by vortex interactions [57]. However, we would like to emphasize that none of the aforementioned effects can explain the observed angular stability of the high-field SC state [39]. Instead, a modification of the FFLO order parameter towards higher-order Landau states is required.
In summary, we presented angular-dependent specificheat measurements of κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 focusing on the suppression of the high-field FFLO state by orbital effects. In particular, we found a large angular stability of the high-field SC phase up to a few degrees, a change of the nature of the SC transition towards first order, as well as the appearance of a second SC state with increasing orbital contributions. The results indicate that the pure FFLO order parameter in κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 transforms into higher-order Landau states with increasing orbital contribution. Angular-resolved measurements on Q2D superconductors, hence, offer the unique opportunity to systematically study new manifestations of superconductivity above the Pauli limit beyond the pure FFLO description.
We acknowledge the support of the HLD at HZDR, member of the European Magnetic Field Laboratory (EMFL) and by the DFG through the WürzburgDresden Cluster of Excellence on Complexity and Topology in Quantum Matter—ct.qmat (EXC 2147, Project No. 390858490) and the ANR-DFG grant Fermi-NESt. JAS acknowledges support from the Independent Research/Development program while serving at the National Science Foundation. Fruitful discussions with T. Gottschall and J. Gronemann are highly appreciated.

Orbital-Induced Crossover of the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov Phase into Abrikosov-like States

In these Supplementary Information, we provide details on the calculation of the H-T phase diagram for κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 as function of the Landau index n and the angle α of the applied field. In particular, we consider the possible impact of the pairing symmetry on the Abrikosov-like states and discuss additional effects which might alter the superconducting phase diagram further. Moreover, the experimental setup for the specific-heat measurements is introduced. Finally, we present additional experimental data, recorded at 21.7 T for negative and positive out-of-plane tilt angles as well as at 19.5 T.
I. INFLUENCE OF THE PAIRING MECHANISM
The paring mechanism in the quasi-two-dimensional (Q2D) organic superconductors is still controversially discussed (see e.g. [S1]). Our study does not aim to answer the controversy, whether the pairing mechanism in κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 has s or d-wave character. However, in these Supplementary Information, we like to point out the influence of the order-parameter symmetry on the high-field superconducting phase diagram and its impact on the higher-order Landau states which are discussed in our manuscript.
In general, the SC order parameter shares the properties of a two-Fermion wave function: it depends on (i) the center-of-mass variable ~R = 12 (~r1 + ~r2) and (ii) the relative variable ~r = ~r1−~r2 of the particles at positions ~r1 and ~r2 that form the Cooper pairs. The length scale for variations with the center-off-mass variable of the order parameter is the coherence length which is much larger than the Fermi wavelength. Accordingly, the spatial modulation of the Abrikosov state and the FFLO phase involve the center-of-mass variation and one anticipates only a minor influence of the order-parameter symmetry on these states and the corresponding phase diagram. However, the classification of the order parameter according to its symmetry properties refers to variations with variable ~r. The dependence on the relative variable is reflected in the variation with the angle on the Fermi surface. As a consequence, the modulation vector characterizing the FFLO state can have preferred directions relative to the nodal lines of a dx2−y2 -order parameter, which it has not for isotropic s-wave pairing symmetry.
The upper critical field for magnetic fields aligned parallel to the conducting layers has been studied in literature for both s-wave as well as for d-wave order [S2–S7]. In the case of dx2−y2 -symmetry, it is important to note that the relative orientation of the modulation vector ~q to the nodal lines of the order parameter changes at low temperatures (top left panel of Fig. S2). While this crossing occurs outside the temperature range considered in the present experiment (T ≈ 0.06Tc), it becomes of importance when discussing the SC transition in tilted magnetic fields.
Following these considerations and the comprehensive discussions given by Shimahara and Rainer [S8], we calculated the critical fields for different tilt angles α assuming both s-wave as well as d-wave order-parameter symmetry.

Using Eqs. (S13) to (S16), we calculated the critical fields of κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 as function of the temperature for selected tilt angles α (Fig. S2). Compared to Fig. S1, the angular stability range of the high-field superconducting phase is slightly reduced for d-wave symmetry. However, qualitatively, one obtains identical behavior for s and d-wave order parameters, proving that the claims of our paper do not depend on the underlying symmetry of the order parameter.
II. FURTHER EFFECTS THAT MIGHT INFLUENCE THE HIGH-FIELD PHASE DIAGRAM IN κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2
Spin-orbit coupling
Concerning spin-orbit interactions, three effects might influence Hc2: (i) Spin-orbit scattering, which is negligible, since the organic superconductors are very clean systems. (ii) Periodic spin-orbit interactions with lattice ions, which is unlikely, since it scales with the proton number to the power of four and κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 contains mostly light elements. (iii) Rashba-type interaction, which can occurs in layered systems from an asymmetry between the top and bottom face, as it was, for instance, treated in Ref. [S15]. However, this interaction would cause an anisotropy of Hc2 with respect to the magnetic-field direction within the plane. Although the latter effect cannot be completely ruled out, it seems unlikely, since a pronounced in-plane anisotropy has never been reported for κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 [S9, S16, S17].

FIG. S2. Calculated H-T phase diagrams of κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 and their variation with angle α. Anisotropic d-wave pairing is assumed. For α = 0, the phase boundary resulting from a d2x−y2-order parameter symmetry is shown for an FFLO modulation vector ~q pointing in nodal as well as anti-nodal direction and is compared to the FFLO solution assuming s-wave symmetry. For tilted field (α > 0), the four independent solution of Eq. (S13) are plotted. The ground state at a temperature T is given by the Landau level with the highest critical field.
Commensurability effects
Commensurability effects could, in principle, exist between the FFLO modulation and the Josephson vortices [S18, S19]. The idea is that nodal lines of the FFLO modulation provide a pinning potential for the coreless Josephson vortices. While this effect will have a strong influence on the electrical resistance of the sample, it cannot account for the strong signatures in specific heat.
Strong-coupling effects
As discussed in our manuscript, κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 is a strong-coupling superconductor. Typically, the strongcoupling leads to an enhancement of the critical fields compared to the BCS expectations [S20]. This effect is included in our discussion.
Interlayer coupling
Strong interlayer coupling causes orbital effects to set in already for fields align in plane. However, as discussed in Ref. [S21], this is not the case for κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2.
Fluctuations
The effect of fluctuations on the Abrikosov-like high-n Landau states has not been studied so far. However, it has been shown that phase fluctuations affect a pure 2D FFLO system more seriously if it has a sinusoidally modulated order parameter than if it exhibits a more complex 2D modulation [S22]. Fluctuations might, therefore, stabilize higher-order Landau states further.
7 III. SPECIFIC-HEAT MEASUREMENTS
We attached the sample to a modified 3He heat-capacity puck (Quantum Design) with a small amount of Apiezon N grease. In order to stabilize the sapphire platform of the puck, while further decreasing its thermal conductivity κth to the bath, the leads connecting the platform were replaced by eight 30 µm Manganin wires and the platform was additionally fixed to the center of the puck using 10 µm Nylon threads [compare Fig. S3(c)]. The puck was screwed to an Attocube ANRv51/LT piezo-driven rotator and placed into a 22 T Oxford Instruments cryomagnet with a HelioxVL 3He insert. The rotator allows for 360° rotation perpendicular to the magnetic field with an experimentally obtained reproducibility of a few 0.01°. The rotation axis was approximately parallel to the crystallographic b axis.
The heat capacity C of the sample was measured using a continuous relaxation method which enables fast measurements, generates a high point density in C, allows to determine hystereses, and is particularly sensitive to first-order transitions [S23, S24]. Figure S3 illustrates the measurement procedure, in particular, the change of temperature [Fig. S3(a)] and heater power [Fig. S3(b)] during a data-acquisition cycle. Starting from the bath temperature T = T0, the platform with the sample on top is heated to T ≈ 3T0. Once a steady temperature is reached, the heater power P is switched off, starting the relaxation of T back to T0. For the heating (T0 → 3T0) as well as for the relaxation (3T0 → T0), the specific-heat C of the sample in the range T0 < T < 3T0 can be calculated from the time derivative of T , the heater power, the predetermined addenda, and the thermal conductance κth [S23]. For a discrete set of times ti and corresponding temperatures Ti, one obtains C via
C(T̄i) = P (ti)− κ̄ ·
( T̄i − T0 )
Ti+1 − Ti (ti+1 − ti) ,
κ̄ = 1 T̄i − T0 · ∫ T̄i T0 κth (T ′) dT ′,
(S17)
in which T̄i = (Ti + Ti+1)/2. Figure S3(d) presents the heat capacity calculated for the two measurements shown in Fig. S3(a). For the 21.3 T data, the transitions arising at Tlow (black dashed line) and Thigh (orange dashed line) are already seen as kinks in the relaxation curves [inset Fig. S3(a)]. Unless noted differently, each C curve presented in our paper is the mean of five measurements.

Data for 21.7 T and α = 5° (gray lines), where the sample is in the normal-conducting state for all temperatures, are shown for comparison. (a) Temperature change during heating and relaxation. IV. DATA MEASURED AT 19.5 T AND 21.7 T
In order to validate if the observed superconducting transitions follow the expected suppression with field, we repeated the angular-resolved specific-heat experiments, discussed in the main part for µ0H = 21.3 T, for slightly higher and lower fields. Figures S4(a)-(p) show the specific heat of κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2 at 21.7 T for selected positive as well as negative angles α. Additionally, relaxation curves are plotted in Fig. S5(a) for selected angles. The curves are similar to the data obtained at 21.3 T (Fig. 3 in the main text), with clear non-equilibrium supercooling effects. We would like to emphasize two observations which prove the intrinsic nature of the measured first-order transition in κ-(ET)2Cu(NCS)2: (i) The features at Thigh and Tlow appear symmetrically around α = 0° verifying that the transitions are only related to the orientation of the applied field to the ET planes. (ii) As expected, Tc, Thigh, and Tlow are slightly reduced compared to 21.3 T. However, the obtained phase diagram [Fig. S5(b)] is qualitatively identical to the one presented in Fig. 4 in the main text. Comparable behavior is found for 19.5 T (Fig. S6), for which Tlow and Thigh are slightly higher.

title: Orbital-Induced Crossover of the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov Phase into Abrikosov-like States
